Article.Abstract: Screening with the flow cytometric IFN-gamma assay has led to the identification of a new immunogenic peptide (SSYRRPVGI) [corrected] from the influenza PB1 polymerase (PB1(703--711)) and a mimotope (ISPLMVAYM) from the PB2 polymerase (PB2(198--206)). CD8(+) T cells specific for K(b)PB1(703) make both IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha following stimulation with both peptides. The CD8(+) K(b)PB1(703)(+) population kills PB2(198)-pulsed targets, but cell lines stimulated with PB2(198) neither bind the K(b)PB1(703) tetramer nor become CTL. This CD8(+)K(b)PB1(703)(+) population is prominent in the primary response to an H3N2 virus, although it is much less obvious following secondary challenge of H1N1-primed mice. Even so, we can now account for >40% of the CD8(+) T cells in a primary influenza pneumonia and >85% of those present after H3N2 --> H1N1 challenge. Profiles of IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha staining following in vitro stimulation have been traced for the four most prominent influenza peptides through primary and secondary responses into long-term memory. The D(b)NP(366) epitope that is immunodominant after the H3N2 --> H1N1 challenge shows the lowest frequencies of CD8(+) IFN-gamma(+)TNF-alpha(+) cells for >6 wk, and the intensity of IFN-gamma staining is also low for the first 3 wk. By 11 wk, however, the IFN-gamma/TNF-alpha profiles look to be similar for all four epitopes. At least by the criterion of cytokine production, there is considerable epitope-related functional diversity in the influenza virus-specific CD8(+) T cell response. The results for the K(b)PB1(703) epitope and the PB2(198) mimotope also provide a cautionary tale for those using the cytokine staining approach to identity antigenic peptides.
Article.ArticleTitle: Diversity of epitope and cytokine profiles for primary and secondary influenza a virus-specific CD8+ T cell responses.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Immunology, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, TN 38105, USA.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Cell lines were generated by six cycles of restimulation with the epitope.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The antigen used in the assay is an author-identified mimotope of this epitope from the PB2 protein of influenza A virus (PB2 198-206: ISPLMVAYM).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Cell lines were generated by six cycles of restimulation with the epitope.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Freshly isolated CD8+/KbPB1 703+ bronchoalveolar lavage cells were were stimulated with the PB2 198-206 (an author identified mimeotope from this study). A similar response was shown when these cells were stimulated with this epitope and PB2 198-206 simultaneously.

Freshly isolated CD8+/KbPB1 703+ bronchoalveolar lavage cells were stimulated with the epitope in order to elicit the response. A similar, but lower response was shown when these cells were stimulated with PB2 198-206 (an author identified mimeotope from this study) and with this epitope and PB2(198-206) simultaneously.
The restriction element for the peptide was determined using the RMAS peptide stabilization assay.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is a mimotope of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope is identified by the authors as a mimotope of a naturally occuring influenza A virus epitope from the PB1 protein: PB1 703-711 (SSYRRPVGI).

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: T cell assay -T cell subset identification

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: T cell assay -T cell subset identification

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CD8+/KbPB1 703+ cells specific for the PB1 703-711 epitope were isolated by bronchoalveolar lavage and were stimulated with the epitope in order to elicit the response.
The response was weak. The peptide also showed weak binding to H-2 I Db.
The response was weak. The peptide also showed weak binding to H-2 I Kb.

Immunologically naïve mice were challenged with influenza A virus and analyzed by a PepC intracellular cytokine assay for the number of CD8+ T cells responding to the epitope. The positive response was elevated in influenza A virus-primed mice. Similar responses were shown in spleen and lymph node cells. In further studies, the cytokine profiles for IFN-γ and TNF-α were shown to increase with time for both primary and secondary responses.
